description: The Despagne family have grand cru classé estates in Saint-Émilion. The same team makes the wine at this neighboring Castillon vineyard. The wine is structured and generous, richly endowed with dark tannins and opulent Merlot. It is a full-bodied wine, open and broadly textured. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Rocher de Joanin 2015  Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This wine's juicy fruit and ripe tannins show it's full of potential. Firm now, it has rich black fruit and perfumed wood flavors that will soften with time. Drink from 2021.
title: Château du Roc 2015  Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This is a ripe, lightly toasty wine, rich with blackberry flavors and showing considerable weight. It offers a touch of licorice, a firm core and the potential to age. This is the first vintage under the Jean-Claude Labrune family for this 130-acre organic Fronsac estate. Drink from 2022.
title: Château de la Dauphine 2015  Fronsac

description: Still very dry and closed up, this hand-picked wine holds promise in its weight. Dark tannins dominate, masking hints of black fruits and rich berries. The wine, produced by Denis Dubourdieu Domaines, needs time, so wait until 2022.
title: Château Haura 2016  Graves

description: A black-currant and spice-flavored wine, this comes from a parcel within the Fougéres vineyard. Aged in oak for 14 months, it has a smooth texture and a minty character that gives richness and style. The wine needs aging, so drink from 2022.
title: Château des Fougéres 2015 Clos Montesquieu  (Graves)

description: This wine revels in its generous fruit and velvet tannins. It is juicy with black fruits and acidity. The structure has a dry core, but the wine's richness and ripe flavors are very much in charge. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Hourtin-Ducasse 2016  Haut-Médoc

description: Owned by the Cruse family, part of the old Bordeaux elite, the estate is in the southern Médoc. The wine, with its firm character and rounded fruit, has weight and considerable richness. It will develop into a plush full-bodied wine. Drink from 2020.
title: Château du Taillan 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: The second wine of Agassac is smooth, full of the fruit of this fresh year. With bright red-berry fruits and soft tannins it is a wine that is developing quickly. It will be delicious and ready to drink from 2018.
title: Château d'Agassac 2014 Pomiés-Agassac  (Haut-Médoc)

description: This wine comes from a vast 460-acre vineyard on the plateau just west of Pauillac. The wood-aging just shows in what is otherwise a ripe and fruity wine. A firm tannic core indicates the youth of the wine rather than masking the fruit. Generous and fruity, this wine will develop well. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Larose Trintaudon 2013  Haut-Médoc

description: Balance makes this wine so impressive. Ripe and rich black fruits are laden with firm tannins without losing sight of their freshness. The structure and solid character of the wine point to good aging. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Devise d'Ardilley 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: One of the largest estates in the Médoc, this misses being in Pauillac by being-literally-on the wrong side of the rail tracks. Regardless, the location ultimately gives the wine depth and richness. It's ripe, dark, dense and very structured, showing the new wood that will integrate. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Larose-Trintaudon 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: Rich and smooth, this concentrated wine is powered by black fruits, berries and plums along with solid tannins that will give it a good period of aging. From the north of the Haut-Médoc, it has similar tannic structure to the wines of its neighbor, Saint-Estéphe. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Maurac 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: Dominated by Cabernet, this is a powerful and structured wine. With dark tannins and concentrated black currant fruits, it's a firm wine that will need time, but has the potential to be well balanced. Owned by the Lurton family, this is a property that's performing well. Drink from 2018.
title: Château de Villegeorge 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: From a small estate, this big, ripe and fruity wine has swathes of black fruits to go with the dark, brooding tannins. Very broad and fruity, the wine is always likely to be structured. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Devise d'Ardilley 2010  Haut-Médoc

description: Dry and serious, this firm wine is classic Bordeaux. It has weight, a core of tannins and black currant fruitiness that needs time to fully integrate with the dense structure. Give this exemplary wine another five years.
title: Château Landat 2011 Vieilles Vignes  (Haut-Médoc)

description: With over 80% Cabernet Sauvignon in the this Kopp family blend, this wine is packed with black currants, ripe tannins and a smoky backdrop from the wood aging. It is structured, dry and juicy at the same time. With this firm core, the wine will need aging, so drink from 2024.
title: Château du Retout 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: The ample fruitiness of this 80% Merlot wine is right up front. It comes from a large 116-acre estate on the extension of the Pomerol plateau. Firm tannins as well as generous black plum and berry fruits are well balanced, just needing time to soften and fill out. Drink this full, rich wine from 2018.
title: Château Siaurac 2014  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This is a serious, complex wine from an estate that was created in the 1930s. Old vines and wood aging have give the wine concentration and richness. Black-plum skin and blackberry flavors, enhanced by a good proportion of Petit Verdot, dominate a wine that will age well. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Vieux Moulin 2014  Listrac-Médoc

description: Still young, with its dry tannins, this is a wine that has developed depth and concentration over the last 3-4 years. It has power, the berry fruits driving through the structure to give a layered, attractive, serious finish.
title: Château Fourcas Hosten 2005  Listrac-Médoc

description: The wine has ripe fruit, tannins that have now softened and signs of maturity. It is still juicy with attractive acidity as well as a touch of spice. Finely balanced, the wine from this Cru Bourgeois estate is elegant and ready to drink.
title: Château Castera 2011  Médoc

description: Coming from the same stable as Léoville las Cases in Saint-Julien, the wine is finely structured with firm tannins and dark fruit. Rich plum flavors are counterbalanced by solid tannins. It needs to age, so drink from 2018.
title: Château Potensac 2011  Médoc

description: Aged for a year in wood, this wine has a toasty character. At the same time, it also has good fruit, plenty of black-currant flavors and acidity. A well-wrought wine, it melds the tannins and fruit into a balanced whole. Drink from 2024.
title: Château La Branne 2015  Médoc

description: From a single parcel in this estate, this wine is a rich Merlot-dominated wine. It has dark tannins and plenty of juicy blackberry fruits that are deeply spiced by the wood aging. It is a full wine, ripe although with a fine streak of finishing acidity. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Tour Bayard 2014 L'Angelot  (Montagne-Saint-Émilion)

description: This is a small property under the same ownership as Château Paloumey. It is unusual in the 20% Petit Verdot that goes into the blend. That gives the wine its deep color and rich generous black-plum fruit. Solid and dense, the wine will age well. Drink from 2020.
title: Château La Garricq 2014  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Under the same ownership as Château Paloumey, this is a small eight-acre vineyard. With 20% of Petit Verdot in the blend, the wine has both great color and a rounded, full-bodied blackberry character. This perfumed wine needs to age, so drink from 2018.
title: Château La Garricq 2012  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: A firmly structured wine, this is powerful and dense. It comes from a 14-acre property dominated by Merlot that gives the wine weight, rich fruit and juicy acidity. The result is a wood-aged wine full of spice and with a dry core that is packed with fruit. Drink from 2025.
title: Château Chemin-Royal 2015  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: This seven-acre property is located to the west of the city of Saint-Émilion on the chalk plateau. This gives the texture to the wine and also the good exposure has added to its richness. Structured with solid tannins and rich with black damson fruits, the wine is ready to age. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Clos Junet 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: A richly perfumed wine, with delicious flavors of raisins, dried plums and sweet tannins. It is an opulent wine, the acidity keeping a watchful eye over the ripeness. It is ready to drink now.
title: Château Andron Blanquet 2003  Saint-Estéphe

description: Boasts layers of wood, with black currant and rich white fig flavors, along with dried fruits. This is a ripe, opulent wine reflecting the heat of 2003 in Bordeaux, but still retaining dry tannins that promise aging.
title: Château Haut-Beauséjour 2003  Saint-Estéphe

description: This vineyard is at one of the highest Castillon points. Big in tannins and also fruit, this is a dense wine. It has a dry core as well as rich blackberry fruits. Concentrated and full, the wine will be seriously worth drinking from 2019.
title: Château Montlandrie 2014  Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Bold and ripe, this rich wine is concentrated and full of spicy black fruits. Produced from a tiny parcel of Petit Verdot that escaped the devastating frost of 1956, it is dark, dense with layers of blueberry flavors alongside the firm tannins. The richness of the wine and its weight promise good aging. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Belle-Vue 2016 Petit Verdot by Belle-Vue  (Bordeaux Supérieur)

description: Ripe and smoky, this offers great fruit that bursts through the tannic structure. The 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon blend is packed with red plum and blackberry fruits that are based upon a solid structure. This will be a fine wine; just wait until 2017. Producer Arnaud Pomme works with co-operative Alliance Bourg.
title: Château Métairie Neuve 2012  Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Maturing well, yet with plenty of aging ahead, this is a firm and fragrant selection. It has a ripe berry flavor and a hint of truffle, with sweet acidity and a dense, rich structure.
title: Château Rahoul 2005  Graves

description: A powerful, firm wine, very solid and rich. With red plum and blackberry fruits, dense tannins and a touch of wood aging, the wine shows considerable potential. It is already balanced but will benefit from at least six years' aging.
title: Château Peymouton 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: A rich, well-balanced wine, this reveals both ripe black plum flavors and sweet tannins. With concentration, full fruits and a layer of acidity, this is an impressive wine for long-term aging.
title: Château le Priolat 2010  Francs Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Consultant Hubert de Bouärd has given this wine a velvey texture as well as rich wood and spice flavors. The wine is generous, full bodied and dense with black fruits. The blend, with 90% Merlot, comes from one of the largest vineyards in Lussac. Drink this rich wine from 2020.
title: Château Lyonnat 2015  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: Low yields and a high proportion of Cabernet Sauvignon have produced an impressive, dense and structured wine. With a smoky backdrop from the wood aging, it has rich black-plum fruit and a serious concentration. It is going to age well, and will be ready to drink only from 2020.
title: Château d'Escurac 2014  Médoc

description: A small proportion of Patrick Bernard's Haut-Médoc estate of Peyrabon is in Pauillac, and he uses the fruit to make a top Cuvée. This wine is suitably powered by dark Pauillac tannins, laced with some new wood and black currant fruits. It's powerful and dense, with considerable aging potential.
title: Château La Fleur Peyrabon 2003  Pauillac

description: This rich barrel-aged wine is a blend of 50-50 Merlot and Cabernet Franc. It is a small, seven-acre estate just outside the village of Saint-Émilion. There are touches of licorice in this wine, hinting at extraction that needs to calm down. When that happens, this will be a dense and finely perfumed wine, rich and with a good future. Drink from 2022.
title: Château la Révérence 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: Parcels of vines on the Phélan-Ségur estate are used for this second label. The wine, with its firm tannins, is developing well. It has structure and a dense texture along with ripe blackberry fruits and acidity. As it develops, it will be generous and ripe. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Phélan-Ségur 2012 La Croix Bonis  (Saint-Estéphe)

description: From the smallest of the Saint-Emilion satellite villages, this wine has swathes of black fruit aromas that go well with its firm tannins, dense blackberry flavors and concentration. Ripe Merlot dominates the blend, giving both structure and fruit. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Saint-André Corbin 2015  Saint-Georges-Saint-Émilion

description: With Hubert de Bouard of Château Angélus in Saint-Émilion acting as consultant, this is an opulent wine. It has great fruits, big tannins that are well integrated into the fruit, and a fine future. Drink this dark and very ageworthy wine from 2017.
title: Château Lyonnat 2010  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: A ripe, full and juicy wine, this is rich with tannins as well as black-currant flavors. Power and concentration are balanced by the fruitiness. Acidity and hints of wood aging add final complexity. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Seguin 2016  Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This rich, concentrated wine is velvet smooth, with tannins enveloped by ripe berry and plum fruits. Wood aging has added to the the rounded character. Despite its approachability, it will age well, so the wine is best drunk from 2018.
title: Château Haut Bertinerie 2012  Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Made with the involvement of Hubert de Bouärd of Château Angélus as consultant, this wine is superrich and packed with dark fruit. Despite its high alcohol for a Bordeaux, it is balanced and fruity with tannins the are comfortably cushioned by the fruit and freshened by acidity. Drink from 2021.
title: Château de Francs 2014 Les Cerisiers  (Francs Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: This ripe, still-young wine is full of tannins as well as rich Merlot fruit. Blackberries, black plums and some ripe tannins are all part of this dense wine. It needs to age until at least 2021 so be patient.
title: Château Renard Mondesir 2015  Fronsac

description: Rich and becoming smooth, this wine is the product of fine ripe Merlot. It is packed with fruit, with tannins that are now integrated and a generous amount of weight and concentration. This is already an attractive wine, although it will be better from 2019.
title: Clos l'Hermitage 2012  Lalande de Pomerol

description: André Lurton bought de Rochemorin in 1973, an estate with vines since the 16th century. This is an aromatic wine, perfumed with blackberry tones. It has plenty of fresh fruit, soft tannins and ample acidity. The structure plays a supporting role-dry while also showing some richness. Drink from 2019.
title: Château de Rochemorin 2013  Pessac-Léognan

description: This is a fruity wine with lovely acidity and a firm background of tannins. The black-currant and berry flavors are up front, giving delicious acidity and a crisp aftertaste. Drink this fruity wine from 2023.
title: Château Couhins 2015  Pessac-Léognan

description: Chocolate and solid fruit flavors in this exemplary wine. It is rich, the tannins balancing with blackberry fruit flavors. The density of the texture suggests good medium-term aging.
title: Château Ormes de Pez 2007  Saint-Estéphe

description: This wine has ripe black fruits to go with its rich tannins. Planted to 90% Merlot and 10% Cabernet Sauvignon, the 22-acre vineyard has produced a wine with solid textures and juicy acidity that point up the weight of the fruit. Drink this generous, spicy wine from 2022.
title: Château Bonnange 2016  Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This rich, structured wine comes from an historic 64-acre estate close to the Garonne river. Spice, black-currant fruits and a good core of tannins all promise aging for this ripe wine. It will be best to drink from 2022.
title: Château de Cérons 2016  Graves

description: The medieval moated castle of Agassac is a fairytale place. The wine, after serious investments, is now showing well. This 2012 is smooth and rich, with black plum fruits and currants giving a ripe feel. The wood aging is already well integrated in this solid, generous wine. Drink from 2018.
title: Château d'Agassac 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: Dark colored wine, revealing wood aging both aromatically and to taste. That said, it also has great weight, a powerful and complex wine with its coffee, dried fruit and black plum flavors. It's an impressive, solid wine that deserves at least seven years' aging.
title: Château Lestage Simon 2010  Haut-Médoc

description: This small 24-acre property has produced a powerful, rich 2010 that layers its big black-plum flavor with complex tannins and wood notes. Dry and firm, it is still defiantly young and needs several years to round out.
title: Bernard Magrez 2010 Château Moulin d'Ulysse  (Haut-Médoc)

description: Solid and powerful, it has a great mix of very ripe fruit with dense tannins. Blackberry fruits, laced with licorice and dark chocolate, contrast with a juicy, lightly herbal element. This mainly Merlot wine is destined for a fine future. Drink from 2017.
title: Château de Roquebrune 2010 Cuvée Reine  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: Owned by the Thomas family, this wine has an unusual blend of 50% Merlot and 35% Petit Verdot (with the rest Cabernet Sauvignon). It shows how Petit Verdot can now ripen easily in warm years. The dark color and dense tannins are a counterpoint to the juicy blackberry fruit. They will allow this wine to age well. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Reverdi 2014  Listrac-Médoc

description: This is a dense and tannic wine. It has plenty of the structure that is common to the Listrac appellation with a firm character when young; however, it also has swathes of ripe black fruits and acidity that will allow it to fill out very satisfactorily. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Cap Léon Veyrin 2014  Listrac-Médoc

description: The Chanfreau family continues its skilled course with this ripe, full and rich wine. Tannins from both the fruit and wood are prominent, giving a dry character to this youthful wine. However, the rich black-currant fruit is developing well. This wine has a long-term future. Drink from 2025.
title: Château Fonréaud 2015  Listrac-Médoc

description: One of the properties that forms the Chanfreau family's Listrac holdings, this 103-acre estate has produced a powerful, rich wine. With tannins still evident, it will obviously age. But ripe blackberry fruit gives the wine a juicy future. It will be ready to drink from 2025.
title: Château Lestage 2015  Listrac-Médoc

description: A quarter century of improvements have made their positive mark on the wines of Marquis de Terme, as revealed in this 2001. It is a generously opulent wine, with its richness and soft tannins, but the spice, the dryness and ripe acidity give it structure and balance. It has good aging potential, but, with its richness, could be drunk now.
title: Château Marquis de Terme 2001  Margaux

description: The moated castle of Issan belongs to the Cruse family, one of Bordeaux's most famous. Under the direction of Emmanuel Cruse, and with consultant Jacques Boissenot, the estate is enjoying something of a renaissance. With its great, generous, rich and sweet fruit, its ripe tannins and its black jelly flavors, it makes a powerful statement. Wood is there, but doesn't dominate. The wine will develop over the next 5-10 years.
title: Château d'Issan 2001  Margaux

description: Not many people have Châteaus named after them. But Caroline Chanfreau-Philippon does and now she runs it as part of Château Lestage, both Cru Bourgeois. This is a rich and structured wine that is concentrated, ripe and juicy. With both attractive black-currant fruits typical of the vintage and firm tannins with tight structure, drink this wine from 2020.
title: Château Caroline 2014  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: One of the reliable wines from Moulis, this vintage of Anthonic shows a ripe, smooth character. Red fruits are underpinned by dusty, ripe tannins. It's going to develop well, although it will need time. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Anthonic 2012  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Ripe, dense and perfumed, this wine offers rich blackberry fruits and generous tannins. It is a structured wine, firm but with swathes of fruit. The estate has been owned by the Carreau family since 1832. Drink from 2021.
title: Château L'Escadre 2016 Grande Réserve  (Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: This ripe wine is dense with firm tannins and bright with red-berry fruits. Dominated by 60% rich Merlot, it is structured while never losing sight of its fruit and spice. The wine is still developing, so don't drink before 2018.
title: Château Haut Bertinerie 2014 Elegance  (Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: This ripe, juicy wine is already attractive and perfumed. Its tannins and wood-aging flavors give weight to its fruit. Spicy and full of black cherry and berry flavors, it's bold and will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Château Cône-Taillasson Sabourin 2015  Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This is a fine wine, with wood and fruit both rich and concentrated. It has spice, juicy black fruits and ripe tannins. It is developing slowly and surely and will be ready to drink from 2019.
title: Château Lamothe de Haux 2014  Cadillac Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Stephan von Neipperg of Château Canon la Gaffeliére was an early proponent of Castillon vineyard potential and chose this property which is on the same ridge as Saint-Emilion. Fruity and ripe, this is a generous wine. Finely structured tannins back up the black-currant fruits and give the wine a texture that bodes well for the future. Drink from 2019.
title: Château d'Aiguilhe 2014  Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux

description: While this dense wine has plenty of firm tannins, it also has fine, ripe fruit. Rich blackberry flavors and smoky aromas dominate. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Haut Dina 2015  Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This huge, rich wine has weight and density. What make it still recognizably Bordeaux are the black currant fruits, acidity and the stylish tannins. Everything else is larger than life, with power and concentration. Drink from 2018. Owners Mallet Fréres use parcel selection for this 80% Merlot and 20% Cabernet Sauvignon blend.
title: Château Haut-Macô 2010 Cuvée Jean Bernard  (Cotes de Bourg)

description: New wood and spice flavors show strongly in this structured wine from 50-year-old vines. It has plenty of spice and ripe blackberry fruits along with a firm aftertaste. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Moutin 2016  Graves

description: Big, dusty tannins dominate this rich and opulent wine. With black plum and juicy red berries, it is well balanced, the acidity cutting through to point up the richness. Very ready to drink, but it will age. Drink now and until 2020.
title: Château Haut Selve 2009 Réserve  (Graves)

description: Powerful tannins still control this wine. It has a mineral-driven texture and is very firm, and the dry core still masks the potential of its delicious, juicy black fruits. Solid and chunky, yet maintaining elegance, this is a wine for aging over at least six years.
title: Château Haut Selve 2008 Réserve  (Graves)

description: Under the same ownership as Château la Dominique in Saint-Emilion, this estate continues to make impressive wine. With its subtle tannins and ripe berry fruits, it is structured while never letting the tannins overwhelm the fruit. It is an impressive wine to age, so drink from 2021.
title: Château Clément-Pichon 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: Rich and concentrated, this is a dark, full-bodied wine. Coming from old vines it has an extra depth of flavor as well as ripe blackberry fruits. It reveals acidity, firm tannins and good aging potential. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Lamothe-Cissac 2012 Vieilles Vignes  (Haut-Médoc)

description: In contrast to the Château wine, this reserve from Château Lamothe-Cissac is for aging. It is still firmly tannic, solid and dark with big ripe fruit and spice from the wood. It holds together well, very balanced. Give it five years.
title: Château Lamothe-Cissac 2005 Vieilles Vignes Réserve  (Haut-Médoc)

description: Just to the north of Saint-Estéphe, this 44-acre estate regularly produces good, structured wines. In this vintage, the structure is right there along with layers of rich blackberry fruits. This is a solid, dense wine, ripe and ready to age well. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Tour Saint-Joseph 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: Under the same ownership as Château Cissac, this ancient estate, dating to the 6th century, is producing some fine wines. This rich vintage is well structured, dense and with classic black-currant Cabernet Sauvignon flavors. Ripe Merlot adds its rich jamminess to a wine that is still young. Drink from 2024.
title: Château du Breuil 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: Under the same management as Château la Dominique in Saint-Émilion, this wine, dominated by ripe Merlot, is full, open and developing quickly. There's a rich edge to the black fruits as well as some powerful tannins that will need to soften. It is an open, generous wine, full of fruit and richly structured. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Clément-Pichon 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: The ancient vineyard of Tour Carnet, first planted in the 15th century, is into a renaissance. This wine, which showed too many tannins when in barrel, is now coming to life. The balance, the acidity and the seductive perfumes promise plenty. So does the structure, just hinting at bitterness, a function of its youthfulness. Keep for 5-8 years.
title: Chateau La Tour Carnet 2004  Haut-Médoc

description: From the first vintage aged in a new cellar, thsi wine is precise, dense and full-bodied wine. Rich black-currant and black-plum flavors contrast with the wine's young structure and acidity. It will age well and should be drunk from 2022.
title: Château de Chambrun 2015  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This is a full-bodied wine, perfumed by its 25% Cabernet Franc and given a juicy fruitcake character by the smooth Merlot. It does still retain a crisper juicy acidity that will develop well as it ages over the next few months. Drink from late 2017.
title: Château Vieux Cardinal Lafaurie 2012  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Smooth and rich, this showcases both the structure and ripe black fruits of the vintage. It has wood-aging flavors, with a touch of caramel and fine acidity. This is for medium- to long-term aging.
title: Château Cap Léon Veyrin 2010  Listrac-Médoc

description: Continuing the sequence of fine vintages from this estate, this wine is rich, dense and structured. It has plenty of tannins, as well as generous black-plum and spice flavors. Wood aging adds light toastiness and smooths out the fruit. Drink from 2025.
title: Château Cap Léon Veyrin 2015  Listrac-Médoc

description: Rich and packed with ripe Merlot-based fruit, this is a solid wine, with a berry flavor and tannins. The delicious, juicy flavors speak to the ripe fruit that needs several years to fully mellow and integrate.
title: Château les Vieilles Pierres 2009  Lussac Saint-Émilion

description: This dense, tannic, complex wine has blackberry and bitter chocolate flavors, with a dark, firm structure. The dusty tannins give weight and richness. Age this for five years.
title: Château Bel-Air 2009 Cuvée Jean-Gabriel  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: A hugely concentrated wine showing chewy, but ripe tannins. Smooth, polished fruit combines with well-balanced wood and suppressed power. This is certainly a wine that will develop well, making it drinkable in five years and mature in 10-15 years.
title: Château Cantenac Brown 2000  Margaux

description: This estate is continuing its fine form with this rich wine. The wood aging is present while leaving plenty of room for the black-currant fruit from the 50% of Cabernet Franc in the blend. The wine is full of attractive fruitiness and a structure that will broaden out as it matures. Drink from 2023.
title: Château d'Escurac 2015  Médoc

description: The wine has weight, tannins and a firm structure. At the same time, its ripe black fruits are developing to fill out the structure and give an impressive wine. Hints of dark chocolate go with the juicy acidity to leave a wine that has several years to develop. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Branas Grand Poujeaux 2014  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: With its firmly tannic core, this is a rich and structured wine. It has a dense, fruit-driven texture, full of very fresh black plum and berry flavors. The tannins provide a dry counterpoint. It's a wine that will age; drink from 2018.
title: Château Baston-Brillette 2012  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Always an attractive wine, Anthonic is in good form in 2008. It has weight as well as fruit, giving a ripe, rounded character to go with its tannins. It feels dense, although not heavy, and has a solid chunky, smoky finish.
title: Château Anthonic 2008  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Produced on a small family-run estate that is surrounded by Bordeaux first growths, this wine is structured and firm. It has dark tannins and black currant fruit, together giving a ripe, smoky wine. The 40-year-old vines add to the concentration of this wine. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Gaudin 2012  Pauillac

description: This is the second wine of Larrivet Haut-Brion. It is rich with tannins and juicy with black-currant acidity. As befits a second wine, it is developing well and easily. Drink from 2021. While it shares the same name as Château Haut-Brion, there is no ownership or location connection between the two properties.
title: Château Larrivet Haut-Brion 2014 Les Hauts de Larrivet Haut-Brion  (Pessac-Léognan)

description: This is a ripe soft wine full of warm fruits and gentle tannins. The second wine of the always-impressive Château Smith Haut Lafitte, it is a rich wine its own right. With black currant and dark plum flavors, it has some solid tannins from 60% Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Smith Haut Lafitte 2013 Le Petit Haut Lafitte  (Pessac-Léognan)

description: A very structured, firm wine with excellent acidity and dark, dry tannins. The alcohol does show through, but the wine is firm and very dense, a big success from this Lurton family owned property.
title: Château Bouscaut 2010  Pessac-Léognan

description: With vineyards to the east of Saint-Émilion itself, this chateau has produced a structured, obviously wood-aged wine. It's a wine still in development, bursting with young black-currant and black-plum fruits as well as acidity. The wood is a strong background presence and will soften over the next few years. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Boutisse 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: Owned by the Riviére family, which also owns a Saint-Émilion-based negociant firm, this estate has produced a generous, ripe wine. The 85% Merlot in the blend gives a jammy, rich character that will soften and broaden as the wine matures. A firm structure within the rich fruitiness will allow the wine to develop. Drink from 2024.
title: Château Cheval Brun 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: The second label of classed growth Château Chauvin, this wine is structured yet bears all the fruit that is characteristic of the vintage. Finely balanced, its acidity and black fruit flavors work together to create a wine that needs to age further. Best from 2020.
title: Château Chauvin 2014 Folie de Chauvin  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Lafon-Rochet is an estate that is producing some very fine wines. This second wine is a good reflection of the quality. With its powerful tannins and dark concentration, it is a still young. Blackberry fruits are paired with the dry core of tannin to give a wine for aging. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Lafon-Rochet 2010 Les Pélerins de Lafon-Rochet  (Saint-Estéphe)

description: Still firm with tannins, this is also a rich, generous wine. It has mint aromas that follow through on to the palate with wood-aging flavors. Bold blackberry fruit and juicy acidity balance the structure and give the wine a ripe character. The wine will be ready to drink from 2018.
title: Château Bel-Air Ortet 2012  Saint-Estéphe

description: The limited-release reserve wine from a 21st century winery and one of the best vineyards in the Graves was wood aged for 24 months. That has given it extra richness and spice along with the dense blackberry fruits. It is complex, ripe with great ageability. Drink this wine from 2019.
title: Château Haut Selve 2014 Réserve  (Graves)

description: This is one of two wines made by Saint-Julien Château Beychevelle from vines in the Haut-Médoc. It has the rich, generous fruit of this vintage, with ripe plum flavors and concentrated tannins. Perfumed acidity and a dry core will allow the wine to age further. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Beychevelle 2015 Les Bruliéres de Beychevelle  (Haut-Médoc)

description: Ripe Merlot gives this wine its richness and concentration. It is filled with black fruits, hints of the wood aging and with tannins cushioned by the fruit. Acidity shows strongly at the end, leaving a bright aftertaste. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Quintus 2014 Le Dragon de Quintus  (Saint-Émilion)

description: A blend of Merlot and Cabernet Franc, this wine is ripe and perfumed. Generous, full tannins are part of the black fruits as well as the solid structure. Wood aging adds spice to the rich mix, giving a wine that conveys dark chocolate, blackberries and plenty of balanced final acidity. Drink from 2021.
title: Clos l'Hermitage 2015  Lalande de Pomerol

description: This is the second wine of Château Pibran, whose vineyard is situated close to those of the the first growths of Mouton and Lafite. Structured and dense, this is a solid, powerful wine, packed with juicy black currant fruits and generous tannins. Give this wine until 2018 before drinking.
title: Château Pibran 2012 Château Tour Pibran  (Pauillac)

description: Wood integrates well with firm tannins in this delicious, ripe and juicy-fruity wine that boasts attractive perfumes. There is density and concentration, a dry edge and ripe acidity. For aging.
title: Château Tour de Lagarde 2008  Saint-Émilion

description: This second wine of classed growth Château Dassault is still young. It has tannins and a dense texture that comes from its rich fruit and high alcohol. However, it's balanced and jammy, with ripe blackberry flavors and a sense of restrained power. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Dassault 2015 D de Dassault  (Saint-Émilion)

description: This is a beautiful, ripe, soft, perfumed wine. Its intense berry fruit is well to the fore, backed by firm tannins. Packed with fruit and smokiness from wood aging, it has strong aging potential. Drink from 2020.
title: Château de Ricaud 2015 Grand Vin  (Cadillac Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: Ripe and structured, this wood-aged wine is still developing. It has a dark structure, dense blackberry fruit and powerful concentration. A peppery touch of alcohol gives it a bitter finish, which should dissipate as it ages. Drink from 2022
title: Château des Landes 2015 Cuvée Prestige  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: Rich and ripe, this wine full of blackberry fruits and balanced tannins has improved since it was reviewed from barrel. It has good concentration for the vintage, dominated by black fruit that offers good acidity at the end. Drink from 2022. Olivier is a large medieval hunting estate that has belonged to the Bethmann family since the 19th century.
title: Château Olivier 2013  Pessac-Léognan

description: This structured wine has juicy acidity as well as big, bold tannins. It's firm and concentrated, a powerful wine that's built for aging. Solid and dense rather than generous, this balanced wine needs many years. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Latour-Martillac 2012  Pessac-Léognan

description: A Merlot-dominated blend, this is rich, balanced and elegant. The wood aging has been well judged to leave hints of spice without losing any of the jammy, ripe black-plum flavors and acidity. As it develops further, this wine will become rich and smooth. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Louvie 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: A dark and dense wine, this offers richness and a good depth of flavor. Along with its concentrated black plum and damson fruits, it is also strongly structured, ripe and dense. It needs aging, so don't drink before 2018.
title: Château Cossieu-Coutelin 2010  Saint-Estéphe

description: Balanced and structured, this rich organic wine is generous and packed with black fruits. Concentration and layers of wood are all part of Jean-François Reaud's fruity wine that will age well. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Les Aubiers 2016  Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Soft and juicy wine, all blackberry fruit and attractive acidity. There is a smoky wood edge just to add extra interest, while tannins are light and sweet.
title: Château Lynch-Moussas 2009  Pauillac

description: Rich with dusty tannins and now-mature fruits, this wine is ripe, full bodied and concentrated. Black-plum flavors are up front along with the smoky flavors, juicy black-currant aftertaste and some further aging potential. Drink now or keep until 2020.
title: Château Valade 2012 Cuvée Renaissance  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Hugely tannic, this formidable wine has great weight, richness and a dark and dense structure. Juicy berry fruits, sweet plum flavors and a dry, concentrated backdrop promise aging. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Haut Bertinerie 2010  Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This is part of a range of wines from the Bantegnies family's estate. It is ripe and juicy with red fruits and spicy tannins. Wood aging gives some extra depth. Ripe fruit, generous tannins and aging potential all point to a wine with a good future. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Haut Bertinerie 2015 Elegance  (Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: This juicy, fruity wine has a great backup of tannins. It has a smoky character, along with black currant fruit, lending an attractive balance. That fruit that will develop well. Drink from 2020.
title: Château L'Escadre 2015 Grande Réserve  (Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: There is a sense of pent-up energy with this wine. It has powerful fruit along with flavors of chocolate, but it is all masked and repressed by tight firm tannins. A wine that will develop slowly.
title: Château Malartic-Lagraviére 2000 Pessac-Léognan  (Bordeaux)

description: The fruit is right up front in this ripe, full wine. With fine tannins and a rich texture, it is spicy, toasty and packed with blackberry fruits. Acidity shows strongly at the end. Along with the tannins, this will allow it to age. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Jalousie Beaulieu 2016  Bordeaux Supérieur

description: Attractively perfumed, this Verdier family wine comes from Merlot/Cabernet Sauvignon vineyards in their first certified French organic vintage. The wine is a smooth and polished. New wood flavors show strongly, after 16 months in barrel, alongside the ripe tannins and black plum fruits. It has rich potential and a strong presence. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Brethous 2012 Cuvée Prestige  (Cadillac Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: A tough, dark wine, needing considerable aging to bring out its balanced fruits. It has the feel of a serious, impressive wine, dominated by powerful tannins. Underneath, the fruit is dark, brooding and firm. Give this wine at least five years.
title: Domaine de l'A 2010  Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Big, rich, dense wine, packed with dark tannins and blackberry fruits. The wine has concentration, layering wood aging with youthful acidity that shines through the structure. An impressive wine that needs aging for at least five years.
title: Château Tour de Guiet 2010 Grand Vin  (Cotes de Bourg)

description: The moated fairy-tale castle of Agassac is a showpiece of the Médoc. This wine is structured, juicy and firm. It has dense dry tannins at this stage although the weight of fruit shows it will develop richly. The wine, with its hints of a blackberry future, will be ready to drink from 2020.
title: Château d'Agassac 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: Produced by the same team as Larose-Trintaudon, this is a structured, Cabernet-dominated wine packed with firm tannins and rich black currant fruits. It's firm and densely tannic. The dry core needs to soften, and will. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Larose Perganson 2012  Haut-Médoc

description: Big, firmly tannic wine, smoky and warm, with great swathes of black currant fruit. It is firmly structured, but it is the rich sweet fruits that are the attraction.
title: Château Citran 2009  Haut-Médoc

description: Dating to the 12th century, this estate now produces a thoroughly modern, ripe wine, full of berries and ripe tannins. Generous Merlot and perfumed Cabernet Franc meld easily together into a wine packed with fruit that will age well for another year or two. It will be best from 2019
title: Château Vieux Cardinal Lafaurie 2014  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Under new ownership, Prieuré-Lichine continues its rapid quality improvement. The wine is concentrated, with dark tannins and brooding fruit, dominated by new wood. It is rich, but also structured for a steady development over 10-15 years.
title: Château Prieuré-Lichine 2000  Margaux

description: The wood that dominated during the futures tastings in 2008 has calmed down, merging more easily into the rich fruits. There is an attractive smoky character, focused berry flavors and delicious spice. It should age well over 3-5 years.
title: Château du Tertre 2007  Margaux

description: The home chateau of the group of properties owned by the Guyon family, this estate has produced a solid very ageworthy wine. It has dark tannins and rich juicy black fruits. With its structure and bright berry and plum flavors, it will not be ready to drink before 2020.
title: Château Rollan de By 2014  Médoc

description: A firm, rich wine that has great potential. The blend of 70% Merlot and 30% Cabernet Sauvignon gives the wine its ripe, berry fruits and fine acidity. Now maturing well, it still has some firm tannins and a dark core that will soften in the next few months. Drink from late 2017.
title: Bernard Magrez 2012 Château la Tempérance  (Médoc)

description: A powerful selection, this is dominated by tannins. Under the firm structure, there is a fruity aspect that will develop. It has the potential to evolve into a full-bodied, intense wine that maintains a sense of elegance.
title: Château Rollan de By 2010  Médoc

description: Big and rich, powered with sweet fruits, rounded with black plums. The firm tannins are densely packed at the core of this ageworthy wine. With its swathes of ripe fruit and the edge of wood aging, it's already delicious, but keep for at least six years.
title: Château Preuillac 2009  Médoc

description: Under any new classification, this should certainly be a classed growth. Today it is among the leaders of the crus bourgeois. The 2000 is opulent, generous, stylish. The tannins are ripe and sweet, the fruit is finely balanced. It will develop well over the next 10-15 years.
title: Château Chasse-Spleen 2000  Moulis

description: An unusual blend for the Médoc of Merlot and Cabernet Franc, this wine comes from a Rothschild vineyard next door to its Château Clarke. The wine is balanced, richly perfumed and spicy with swathes of black-currant fruit and ripe tannins. Developing slowly, the wine needs some time. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Malmaison 2015  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: Made by the same team as neighboring Château Chasse-Spleen, the wine from this 17-acre estate is fruity, with the potential for a smooth texture and rich fruit. The wine has spice, juicy black currants and a delicious aftertaste. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Gressier Grand Poujeaux 2015  Moulis-en-Médoc

description: This wine is smoky with sweet tannin and firmer wood flavors. It offers fresh, succulent fruitiness as well, with berry fruits that give fullness and density. Big and concentrated, this needs to age. Drink from 2019.
title: Château Seguin 2012  Pessac-Léognan

description: This selection from different parcels in the Latour-Martillac vineyard is released when the chateau believes it is ready to drink. This wine is showing attractive signs of maturity as well as some of the tannins that mark out this vintage. It will probably remain on the dry side, meaning it will always be a food wine. Drink now.
title: Château Latour-Martillac 2011 Lacroix-Martillac par Latour-Martillac  (Pessac-Léognan)

description: This vintage is richly endowed with black fruits and ripe tannins. It has weight, layers of wood aging, acidity that plays with the smoky berry flavors and rounded aftertaste. The estate dates back to the 14th century, although vines were not planted until the 19th. Drink the wine from 2021.
title: Château de Lescours 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: One of three de Gaye family estates, this small 17-acre proprerty has produced an intense wine, black with dark tannins and black-plum flavors. There is no doubt about the weight of the wine and it has plenty of fruit to balance the big tannins and dark-coffee flavors. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Grand Corbin Manuel 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: This is a generous ripe wine. It is full of rich black fruits that are cut with acidity as well as fleshed out with firm tannins. Dense and still dry, this young wine needs to age further. Drink from 2021.
title: Château du Parc 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: A powerful, solid wine, its dark fruits fitting well with the wood, the firm tannins and black plum flavors. This is made for aging, as it is just starting to show its depth.
title: Château Corbin 2006  Saint-Émilion

description: Full of the bright fruit typical of the vintage, this wine is made from 90% Merlot with a touch of Cabernet Franc. It's structured with still-young tannins and is dominated by red berry fruit, needing to age until 2021.
title: Château Tour Grand Faurie 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: Fresher and more floral than the 2003, with flavors that run toward mulberry while adding hints of vanilla and maple syrup. It's richer, creamier and longer than the 2003, showing the results of Seillan having full control over the property for the entire year. Drink now-2015.
title: Château Vignot 2004  Saint-Émilion

description: The are firm indications of wood aging in this wine, meaning it needs some time. For now, it is all spice and exuberant blackberry fruits. As it develops, it will integrate well to produce a rich wine with plenty of blackberry and damson fruits. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Laffitte Carcasset 2015  Saint-Estéphe

description: A very dry wine, it shows the traditional Saint- Estéphe hard tannins. That suggests it will develop slowly, gradually bringing out the potential of the red berry fruits and acidity as it develops into a fine, complex wine. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Cos Labory 2011  Saint-Estéphe

description: Pure Merlot, this wine comes from a property that borders on Pomerol proper. Its juicy red-berry flavors are classics for the vintage. Ripe while crisp and with acidity balancing the tannins, the wine is developing well. It should be ready to drink from 2021.
title: Château de Roquebrune 2014 Cuvée Reine  (Lalande de Pomerol)

description: Produced from a parcel of 50-year-old Cabernet Sauvignon, with a touch of Malbec, this wine is aged in large wooden barrels for two years. The organically grown grapes give a crisp purity to the wine, bringing out black currants, crisp acidity and firm tannins. The wine will age well, drink from 2021.
title: Château de Lagarde 2015 La Joly Vin Biologique  (Bordeaux Supérieur)

description: Black fruits dominate this second wine of Kirwan, an 1855 Third Growth Grand Cru Classé. The oak aging is subtle and gives a smooth character rather than strong toasty flavors. The richness and structure do promise some aging although this wine will develop quickly. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Kirwan 2014 K de Kirwan  (Margaux)

description: This is a delicious ripe wine, full of black fruits and with generous tannins. Mint flavors come from the new wood aging and enhance the ripe berry flavors and acidity. Drink this structured wine from 2018.
title: Château Beauséjour 2014 Cuvée Spéciale  (Puisseguin Saint-Émilion)

description: Produced from organically grown grapes, the wine is rich and structured. It comes from an estate that has never seen pesticides or artificial fertilizers (the previous owner was 104 years old when she died and never used them). It is a full of blackberry fruits, rich with tannins and firm with a dark core of dryness. Drink this wine from 2020.
title: Château Coutet 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: Dark, dry tannins are what good Saint-Estéphe is all about when young, and de Pez doesn't disappoint. But it does more, with refined black plum skin flavors, a rich mix of spices and mint, and a refreshing streak of acidity. In 4-5 years, this will be an outstanding wine.
title: Château de Pez 2004  Saint-Estéphe

description: This Alliance Bourg co-op wine is packed with minty new-wood aromas, this has the potential to be a smooth, polished wine. The blend is 70% Merlot, 20% Cabernet Sauvignon and 10% Cabernet Franc. Firm tannins at this stage do not mask the ripe blackberry fruits. Give this wine until 2019 before drinking.
title: Closerie du Bailli 2014 Grande Réserve  (Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: Potentially an aromatic wine that will develop a rich, velvety character. At this young stage, the fruit is dominated by firm tannins that sit at the heart of the wine. It has all the density for a good development, aging over 5-10 years.
title: Château la Bessane 2008  Margaux

description: This rich, dense wine is opulent and full of black fruits. The very ripe Merlot has given concentration, dark tannins and berry flavors, as well as the alcohol. Wood aging has made the wine, if anything, richer. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Ambe Tour Pourret 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: This ripe, bold wine is balanced and full of well-structured tannins and fruit. With concentration plus a solid and dark base of black-plum flavors, the wine has excellent potential. Drink this full wine from 2022.
title: Union de Producteurs de Saint-Émilion 2016 Château Terre de Grand  (Bordeaux Supérieur)

description: From a tiny organic vineyard, this dense wine is packed with tannins while still having plenty of fruit weight. Its black-plum flavors are already delicious, backed up by the impressive structure and concentrated texture. Drink from 2022.
title: Clos Louie 2016  Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This complex, structured blend of 60% Cabernet Sauvignon and 40% Merlot offers ripe tannins and layers of attractive black fruit. Showing its potential, the wine is dense and full of fruitiness as well as tannins. Drink from 2022.
title: Château de Cranne 2016 6éme Génération  (Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: The luxury Cuvée from this estate, this blend includes 70% Merlot and 30% Malbec. It is still wood laden, with strongly toasty flavors that are balanced by opulent black fruits and firm tannins that promise a richly succulent wine. It will need plenty of time, so don't drink before 2022.
title: Château Martinat 2015 Cuvée Epicurea  (Cotes de Bourg)

description: Owner Xavier Chassagnoux bought this estate in 1978, producing this as the top wine of the property. It shows the richness and fruitiness of the vintage, a ripe wine with black-plum fruit and touches of wood aging as well as crisp acidity at the end. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Renard Mondesir 2012  Fronsac

description: This 55% Cabernet Sauvignon and 45% Merlot blend comes from an estate just north of Saint-Estéphe. It reflects the structure and density of that appellation. Bold, ripe and fruity, it will age well. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Maurac 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: With its 90% Merlot, this is a classic wine from this region of Bordeaux. It is rich, balancing the elegant blackberry fruits with acidity. A succulent texture will soften as this sophisticated wine matures, so drink from 2022.
title: Château Tournefeuille 2015  Lalande de Pomerol

description: Dating to the Middle Ages, this estate has produced a Merlot-dominated wine packed with dark tannins and a dusty texture that is becoming more elegant as it ages. The wine is still young and full of its concentrated structure. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Ambe Tour Pourret 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: This wine comes from a rare estate, in the same family since 1537, that has never used chemicals in the vineyard. The wine is richly endowed, spicy and juicy with soft tannins and a pure, crisp texture. It is poised, elegant and waiting to age further. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Coutet Saint-Emilion 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: Still very young, this ripe Merlot-dominated wine is packed with dark plum and rich damson fruit flavors. They balance the serious amount of wood influence that gives it its spice and ageability. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Tour Grand Faurie 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: The wine is ripe and full of blackberry fruits. It has serious tannins still although these are well balanced by the fruitiness. The firm structure and wood aging flavor will soften over the next few years. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Fourcas Dupré 2014  Listrac-Médoc

description: This ripe, impressively textured wine is going to be rich and generous. Not just yet, because the tannins need to soften and integrate. That said, the blackberry fruits are juicy, with balanced acidity and a full texture. Drink this wine from 2022.
title: Château Paveil de Luze 2015  Margaux

description: This is a fine wood-aged blend of 57% Cabernet Sauvignon with Merlot and Petit Verdot. It is darkly colored, dense and with great ripe tannins. One of several Bordeaux properties owned by the Thiénot family, this estate occupies a fine, gravel outcrop in the Pessac-Léognan region, just south of Bordeaux. Drink from 2024.
title: Château la Garde 2014  Pessac-Léognan

description: This a finely perfumed wine with its 32% Cabernet Franc, unusual for this estate. It gives a wine with great structure and concentration as well as layers of ripe black fruits. The wine needs to age so drink from 2023.
title: Château Nenin 2014  Pomerol

description: With the high alcohol typical of 2010 vintage, this is a ripe, jammy and full wine. Black plums ooze richness against a background of firm tannins and acidity that will allow the wine to age. It is dense, concentrated and powerful, needing some time. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Beauséjour 2010  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: From parcels within the Phélan-Ségur vineyard, this wine is juicy although with the tannins typical of the appellation. With its powerfully structured, rich blackberry fruits and acidity, it is likely to age well, giving a wine ready to drink from 2023.
title: Château Phélan-Ségur 2015 La Croix Bonis  (Saint-Estéphe)

description: This Roederer-owned property has produced an impressive wine this vintage. Full, plump and rich, and packed with firm black fruits which are layered with fine, pure acidity. This is a wine that is likely to age, over 5-10 years. Imported by Maisons Marques & Domaines USA.
title: Château de Pez 2003  Saint-Estéphe

description: Eucalyptus aromas add to the ripe fruit in this wine to give both structure and fine potential. With its black plum flavors, rich texture and warm character, it's impressive and ready to age. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Gauthier 2015  Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux

description: The wine, from one of the five Aubert family properties, is rich and full of great fruit. With ripe tannins and blackberry generosity over the wood aging, this is still structured yet ready to drink.
title: Château de Ribebon 2015  Bordeaux Supérieur

description: From organic and biodynamic vineyards, this wine is full of ripe berry fruits backed up by firm tannins, this is a wine that is full of potential. It has structure, a fine form of rich fruit and acidity. With its dense texture this is a wine to age. So just wait until 2019.
title: Château Brethous 2014  Cadillac Cotes de Bordeaux

description: This well-balanced, ripe wine is firmly full of tannins and rich with black fruits. Its concentration and acidity are layered with licorice and toast flavors, all suggesting the need for aging. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Hyot 2015 Réserve  (Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: Owned by one of the top wine families in nearby Pomerol, this is a structured and finely ripe wine. It has great balance between the tannins and the black currants. Packed with fruit and the barest hints of wood aging, it is developing well and will be ready from 2018.
title: Château Tessendey 2014  Fronsac

description: Produced by the team from classed growth Château Giscours, this is a successfully ripe wine with smoothly integrated tannins. Cushioned by the ripe fruit, the structure is concentrated and impressive. Drink this wine from 2022.
title: Château Duthil 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: The great dominance of Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend has given this wine both a fine structure and crisp swathes of black-currant fruit. It is a firm wine at this stage, although the fine fruitiness will become an important part of the taste. The estate is named after one of Napoleon's generals who became King of Sweden. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Bernadotte 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: Almost black in color, this is a solid, firm and ripe wine. It has a smooth wood character that is round and rich with black plum and berry fruit flavors. With its dark underlying texture, it will age, so drink from 2017.
title: Château Larose Perganson 2011  Haut-Médoc

description: Formerly the property of one of Napoleon's generals, this estate is now performing impressively after renovations. This wine is richly structured and packed with black fruits. Dark tannins vie with black currants and ripe spice in this wine that will age well. Drink from 2024.
title: Château Bernadotte 2015  Haut-Médoc

description: Plenty of attention seems to have been lavished on this wine produced from the best parcels on the estate. It offers dense tannins, new-wood mint flavors and an edge of extraction in the bitter-chocolate flavors. With time this will be a rich wine, but one balanced and based around fruit and tannins. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Haut-Piquat 2015 La Fleur de Château Haut-Piquat  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: This is a wine that brings out all the bright fruit of the vintage. It has classic black-currant flavors and crisp acidity. The tannins are a firm supporting act to this wine that will develop well over the medium term.
title: Chateau d'Angludet 2014  Margaux

description: From one of the properties controlled by Marie-Laure Lurton, this is a finely made wine. It revels in its structure, while around that there are ripe, soft red berry fruits, spice and an intensely juicy acidity. Full of charm, ready to age.
title: Château la Tour de Bessan 2008  Margaux

description: While not strictly part of the Haut-Médoc Château Cambon la Pelouse, this small parcel in Margaux is under the same ownership and vinification. The wine has weight, some solid fruit, with the wood adding polish but not dominating. A well-structured wine for medium-term aging.
title: Château Cambon la Pelouse 2007 L'Aura de Cambon  (Margaux)

description: The vines of this Domaines Rodrigues-Lalande estate grow around the village of Martillac, neighboring some of the area's top classed-growth estates. The wine, well balanced between Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, is rich while well structured with spice and tannins. With its great fruit and ripe character, the wine will age. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Roche-Lalande 2015  Pessac-Léognan

description: While there are plenty of wood-aging flavors at this young stage of the wine, the weight of black fruits and generous texture promise a ripe future. The wine, with its 80% Merlot is juicy, full and packed with richness. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Franc Maillet 2014 L'Esquive  (Pomerol)

description: This rich wine, produced from old vines, is dense and concentrated. It does have the fruitiness of the vintage but that is allied to the dark-black fruit and powerful tannins. There are spice and wood flavors still developing. Drink this fine wine from 2020.
title: Château Lanbersac 2014 Cuvée Vieilles Vignes  (Puisseguin Saint-Émilion)

description: This sumptuous wine is generous and packed with fruit. Behind the swathes of ripe black-plum flavors lie firmer tannins and a dense structure that will allow the wine to age. Drink this rich wine from 2022.
title: Clos Labarde 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: The wine is rich and ripe, revealing purity of fruit as well as prominent new wood flavors. Otto Rettenmaier, whose cellar is full of wooden cuves named after opera stars, now operates in a biodynamic way and that seems to give an intensity of flavor as well as lusciousness and opulence. Drink from 2010.
title: Château La Tour Figeac 2000  Saint-Émilion

description: An elegant grand cru whose tannic structure is just beginning to resolve. Has a nose of berry aromas, earthy accents and even meaty notes. The palate displays developed ripe cassis and earth flavors. Still youthful, it drinks well, but should evolve further over the next few years.
title: Château Yon Figeac 1995  Saint-Émilion

description: Still with intense tannins, this Merlot-dominated blend is young. The fruitiness is all there with ripe smoky fruit and blackberry flavors. It just needs a while for the tannins to soften into ripe generous fruitiness. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Cormeil-Figeac 2014  Saint-Émilion

description: Bringing out the richness of this vintage and its generous fruit, this wine is dense and packed with succulent black fruits. Crisp acidity adds to the fruitiness of the wine, while also underlining the firm structure that needs to soften. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Pontet Fumet 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: This is a monster of a wine. 100% very ripe Merlot, it shows a power and density that is still firm and structured. With age, that concentration will turn into beautiful richness. But don't doubt its power. Drink from 2021.
title: Château Tour Grand Faurie 2010  Saint-Émilion

description: Immediately delicious with its licorice, black fruit and spice combo, this is a rich wine, hedonistic almost, soft in structure. There is no aging needed here, for with its softness and super-ripeness, this needs to be drunk-and with pleasure-over the next year.
title: Château Corbin Michotte 2005  Saint-Émilion

description: The aromas are all dominated by new wood. But to taste, this super cru bourgeois is all about fruit. It is sweet, generous, not having typical Saint-Estéphe tannins, but showing more elegance. A great success.
title: Château Haut-Marbuzet 2000  Saint-Estéphe

description: The second wine of Château Meyney comes from one of the top estates of the appellation. From selected parcels and barrels of wine, this shows the same sense of structure as the top wine, while the fruitiness is developing more quickly. The black currant and plum-juice flavors are already bursting from the tannins. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Meyney 2010 La Chapelle de Meyney  (Saint-Estéphe)

description: One of the great estates of southern Saint-Julien, producing wines whose regularity in succeeding vintages is remarkable. For 2003, Branaire has produced a dark wine, with dry, powerful tannins coming from very ripe fruit. The wood is dry and toasty, leaving a general impression of a wine that will age at a stately pace. Imported by Diageo Chateau & Estates.
title: Château Branaire-Ducru 2003  Saint-Julien

description: Definite tannins here, a wine that shows ripe fruits, richness and a solid core. It is not huge, but does have structure, bitter chocolate, sweetness. It's worth aging this wine 3-4 years.
title: Château Léoville Las Cases 2007 Clos du Marquis  (Saint-Julien)

description: This perfumed wine offers rich tannins, layers of new-wood aging and plenty of spice. The black-currant fruits also show ripe potential. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Moutin 2016 Grande Cuvée  (Graves)

description: One of the exciting wines produced by this go-ahead cooperative in Blaye, this is pure Petit Verdot. Dark in color, packed with firm tannins and impressive black fruits, it is a wine to age for several years. Drink from 2022.
title: Les Vignerons de Tutiac 2015 Lieu-dit Verdot  (Bordeaux)

description: This 30-acre estate lies in the heart of the Montagne appellation. From 35-year-old vines, this wine is ripe, generous and full of black fruit. It has a dense structure, full of oak-aging tannins and with touches of dark chocolate. Acidity gives the wine a lift at the end. Drink from 2023.
title: Château Forlouis 2015  Montagne-Saint-Émilion

description: This structured, concentrated wine is from an estate in the north of Saint-Estéphe. A dominance of Cabernet Sauvignon in the blend lends it firm, solid tannins as well as a juicy black-currant note. It's a wine for long-term aging; don't drink before 7-8 years.
title: Château Beau-Site 2010  Saint-Estéphe

description: Almost black, this dense wine is powered by dusty tannins that underly the ripe black plum fruits, intense juiciness and solid concentration. The considerable wood does not spoil the fruitiness of the wine. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Pontoise Cabarrus 2011  Haut-Médoc

description: From a small parcel of land that is not designated as classed growth (rare in Pauillac), this is a richly satisfying wine. It is full of complex tannins as well as juicy red-berry fruits. There is also structure to give it the chance to age. Drink this wine with its delicious potential from 2022.
title: Domaine de Saint-Guirons 2014  Pauillac

description: This 11-acre, family-owned property has produced a generous, opulent wine. A blend of 75% Merlot with Cabernet Franc, it shows the ripeness of the fruit in this vintage giving a rich, dark plum-flavored wine. Tannins lie at the core of this cushion of fruit. Still young, it needs time and will be best from 2020.
title: Château Gouprie 2015  Pomerol

description: The Carreau cousins, Nicolas and Sébastien, continue to make waves with this 2015 acquisition of the chateau. This balanced and structured wine spent six months in old oak barrels. Its blackberry fruits are ably assisted by the generous tannins and dry core. This rich wine will age well, ready to drink from 2022.
title: Château Le Cap 2016 Cuvée Tradition  (Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: Rich and structured, yet full and concentrated, this wine has both dark tannins and ripe plum and berry fruits. The acidity streaks through the wine, lending freshness and good aging potential. Drink from 2017.
title: Château de Belcier 2011  Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux

description: Ripe and soft, this is a smooth, dense wine. Yes, it has plenty of tannins, but they're smothered by the concentrated black fruit that gives it its generous, rich character. It's likely to age well, so drink from 2020.
title: Château Moulin de Guiet 2015  Cotes de Bourg

description: Full of bright red-berry flavors and spiced with the wood aging, this is a generous, fruit-driven wine. The tannins are still softening but already the wine is attractively balanced. Keep this wine for a few more years and drink from 2020.
title: Château de la Riviére 2014  Fronsac

description: A structured, Cabernet Sauvignon-dominated wine that is already showing its ripe juicy side. It is already impressive, with its layers of butts as well as acidity. The black-currant fruitiness of the vintage is shining through. Currently performing well, this property is at the southern end of the Haut-Médoc region. Drink the wine from 2019.
title: Château Paloumey 2014  Haut-Médoc

description: Dark in color, this is a concentrated wine that's very firm in structure, with dense tannins. It's powered by ripe, mature black fruits as well as acids that cut through the dry texture. This needs several years of aging.
title: Château Lamothe-Bergeron 2010  Haut-Médoc

description: Owned by the Hessel family since the 15th century, this estate has produced a dense and solid Merlot-dominated wine. It is big and bold with ripe berry fruits and dark tannins. The black plum skin and berry flavors are concentrated and firm. It needs to age, so drink from 2018.
title: Château des Annereaux 2012  Lalande de Pomerol

description: One of the stars of Margaux, Monbrison 2001 is packed with rich, powerful black fruits, with open, generous fruit flavors and great new-wood flavors. This is an impressive, modern wine, powered with dense fruit, as well as some elegance and style.
title: Château Monbrison 2001  Margaux

description: The heavy bottle, as so often, is the giveaway: This is meant as an important statement. The wine comes from a small parcel of vines owned by Cambon la Pelouse in Margaux. It has 100% new wood, but the richness of the fruit balances, giving a smooth, rich wine with black berry, bitter chocolate and mint flavors.
title: Château Cambon la Pelouse 2008 L'Aura de Cambon  (Margaux)

description: This is a solid, finely perfumed wine, the tannins giving concentration and structure. There is some severity as well, a sign that it is still settling into the bottle. But with its bitter chocolate character and tight texture, it should age well.
title: Château Kirwan 2007  Margaux

description: This wine is dry, full of tannins and dark fruits. It is weighty, structured and ready for the long term with its acidity, dry tannins, dense structure and intense black currant fruits. Drink this mineral-textured wine from 2020.
title: Château Carbonnieux 2012  Pessac-Léognan

description: A great success, with its concentration, solid tannins and black, bitter cherry fruit flavors. The wine has spice, licorice and some layers of wood. Certainly, this would be worth aging for 4-5 years.
title: Domaine de Chevalier 2007  Pessac-Léognan

description: This rich and dense wine is maturing well. It has a solid texture, touches of dark chocolate as well as juicy blackberry flavors underlined by wood aging. The tannins need to soften further; drink from 2020.
title: Château Pape Clément 2014 Les Clés de Pape Clément  (Pessac-Léognan)

description: This 22-acre property produces wines dominated by 90% Merlot. That gives ripe juicy red-fruit flavors, rich tannins and density. There is also a strong streak of acidity that shows vividly. The wine will soften over the next few years and give a delicious drink from 2021.
title: Château Bourgneuf 2014  Pomerol

description: With 30% of the harvest aged in new oak, this is a spicy, toasty wine. That shows through in the firm tannins that back up the rich black fruit. Produced from 30-year-old vines, it has concentration and a fine, solid texture. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Haut-Bernat 2015  Puisseguin Saint-Émilion

description: This is the second wine from Premier Grand Cru Classé estate La Gaffeliére, made from a selection of vines and barrels. It is rich and very ripe with bold black-fruit flavors and a dark, firm structure. The wine is already in balance, showing that it will develop quickly and attractively. Drink from 2018.
title: Château la Gaffeliére 2013 Clos la Gaffeliére  (Saint-Émilion)

description: Chocolate and ripe black fruits go with a lively, spicy acidity that gives the wine a great lift. It is lively and concentrated.
title: Château Laforge 2008  Saint-Émilion

description: A wine with some density, spiced with touches of wood, dusty tannins and an open sweet plum flavor. There is plenty of wood here, layering the fruit. The wine has aging potential, worth waiting 4-5 years.
title: Château Beausejour-Duffau-Lagarrosse 2007  Saint-Émilion

description: From a vineyard on the Saint-Émilion plain below the village, this wine offers firm tannins and a balance between ripe berry fruits and acidity. Spice and dryness come from the wood aging. The wine has power through the dark density of its tannins, so wait to drink until 2023.
title: Château Lalande de Gravet 2015  Saint-Émilion

description: Now mature, this juicy, ripe wine has begun its change into secondary flavors. It's still firm, with layers of spice and acidity, yet has developed a warm, rich density that will stay for several years.
title: Château Laroque 2012  Saint-Émilion

description: This generous wine is ripe with seductive black fruits and rich tannins. The Merlot gives this wine its juicy, jammy character absorbing the tannins like a sponge. It comes from red clay soil (Terres Rouges) that brings extra richness to this full-bodied wine. Drink from 2022.
title: Château Tour du Moulin 2015 Les Terres Rouges  (Fronsac)

description: A highly perfumed wine, with enticing aromas. The palate is tougher, unforgiving, the young structure there to support fresh and concentrated fruit. There is a definite wood element, but it is not overdone. For aging 3-4 years.
title: Château Bellerose Figeac 2006 Prestige  (Saint-Émilion)

description: It's the 100% Merlot that gives the alcohol and superripe fruit to this wine, redeemed by the acidity. Licorice and dark chocolate flavors go with the sweetest plums and spice. Age for 3-4 years.
title: Château Lyonnat 2009 Emotion  (Lussac Saint-Émilion)

description: Here's a new wood-aged young wine, with ripe fruit and mint aromas. The wine does have a bitter edge of extraction that detracts from the generous black fruitiness. It is certainly firm at this stage-a full-bodied wine with a dark-fruit character at the end. Drink from 2020.
title: Château Gaby 2014  Canon-Fronsac

description: From one of those rare properties in Pauillac that are not classified growths, this wine is ripe, dark, still smoky and very structured. It has some of the weight of the vintage although in a restrained way, giving juicy black currant fruits behind the tannic structure. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Gaudin 2010  Pauillac

description: Firm tannins are well integrated with the black-currant fruits in this dense, ripe and very fruity wine. It is juicy and perfumed with a generous texture and good freshness. The Merlot sings in this wine, bright and structured. Drink from 2021.
title: JCP Maltus 2015 Château Laforge  (Saint-Émilion)

description: The second wine of Château Glana in the prestigious Saint-Julien appellation is properly tannic with fruit in the background. The wine will develop well, but will still require some time. Its juicy black-currant fruitiness and acidity have power and concentration-enough to produce a ripe, while still elegant wine from 2020.
title: Château du Glana 2014 Terre du Lion  (Saint-Julien)

description: Mint aromas signal the wood aging of this ripe wine. It is named after François Carreau, credited with being the first in Bordeaux to graft rootstock onto vines to protect against phylloxera. The wine is full, poised between big tannins and equally important dark fruits. This impressive wine will age well, but will not be ready before 2022.
title: Château L'Escadre 2016 Major  (Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: From 7.5 acres of Merlot and Cabernet Sauvignon, this is a rich wine, very perfumed and with layers of ripe fruit. It is lightly structured, full of red berries with a firm tannic character in the background. Under winemaker Olivier Dauga, the wine needs to age but has all the fruit potential there. Drink from 2018.
title: Château Cantinot 2012 Orbite de Cantinot  (Blaye Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: This ripe, juicy and smoky wine is rich in black fruit. It's structured and full, the fruit layered with wood. Perfumed now, it promises a good future ahead. Drink from 2021.
title: Château du Roc 2015 Libelula by Roc  (Castillon Cotes de Bordeaux)

description: While the wine is all tannin and structure at this stage, the weight and rich fruit promise plenty of good aging potential. Wine producers for 10 generations, the Dulon family picks specific plots. This 60% Merlot, 35% Cabernet Sauvignon and 5% Cabernet France blend has juicy black fruits that will push forward to give a full wine with a fine presence. Drink from 2017.
title: Château du Vallier 2012  Cotes de Bordeaux

description: As so often, the wine is foursquare, tough and dark. It has powerful tannins with the weight of fruit well behind at this stage, structure to the front. It needs several years to come into balance.
title: Château Haut Bages Libéral 2009  Pauillac

description: This is a blend of grapes from different growers in Pomerol rather than a second wine of Château Clinet. It is made to be drunk young with its smooth tannins, generous texture and ripe Merlot fruits. It feels rich and sumptuous, a rounded wine that is lightly topped by tannins. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Clinet 2011 La Fleur de Clinet  (Pomerol)

description: This wine shows mint aromas and big black-fruit flavors. With high toast wood aging, it feels extracted, with bitter chocolate paralleling the blackberry fruits. It has considerable power and density and needs aging. Drink from 2017.
title: Château Vray Croix de Gay 2011  Pomerol

description: This wine's black cherry and plum flavors veer dangerously toward prune-no doubt a product of the exceedingly hot summer. It's creamy and supple in texture, adding just enough tobacco, vanilla and smoke for complexity. But for all the fruit and ripeness, it finishes with great elegance and precision. Drink now-2020. Imported by Acadia Imports.
title: Lasségue 2003  Saint-Émilion

description: A perfumed, finely structured wine, with firm, dusty tannins. The wood is well-balanced with acidity and some generous weight, finishing with black fruits and intense freshness.
title: Château la Gaffeliére 2007  Saint-Émilion

description: Big, rich and elegant, this wine has fine, lifted black fruits layered over dry new wood and fruit tannins. It is certainly firm, and needs at least 4-5 years' aging, but it will develop into a sophisticated, balanced wine.
title: Château Laroque 2005  Saint-Émilion

description: Jammy and ripe, from gravel soils in the valley plain of Saint-Emilion, this is already a very drinkable wine. It has intense, concentrated red and black berry fruits surrounding a core of seriously dry tannins from fruit and wood. Solid but rich, this is developing well.
title: Château Laforge 2006  Saint-Émilion

description: This is a very new-wood dominated wine, that will appeal to lovers of California Cabernet. Blackcurrant jelly fruits are there as well, very modern, very polished. It is a fine wine, but maybe not Bordeaux.
title: Château Talbot 2000  Saint-Julien
